Mark Levison wrote:
> In our current architecture - we say that a method should either
> accept Null, an EmptyString, etc. as a valid input or it should throw
> an ArgumentException (AE). So in our world view a NPE indicates a
> coding error inside the API. I like the distinction an AE says that
> the API is not being used correctly whereas a NPE says the API is
> broken.
I will throw NullPointerExceptions when a client passes an incorrect 
null parameter.  From the javadoc:

"Applications should throw instances of this class to indicate other 
illegal uses of the |null| object."

Are there bugs that are avoided by having an application change all the 
NPE's it could throw into AE's?

    David Saff
